sen.j: 田辺玄々（たなべ げんげん、男性、寛政8年（1796年） – 安政5年12月18日 (旧暦)（1859年1月21日））は、江戸時代後期の日本の書家・篆刻家である。
sen.e: Gengen TANABE (a male, 1796 - January 21, 1859) was a calligrapher and Tenkoku artist (a carver who carved Chinese characters in the special, Tensho, style) who lived in Japan in the latter half of the Edo period.

Gengen TANABE (a male, 1796 - January 21, 1859) was a calligrapher and Tenkoku artist (a carver who carved Chinese characters in the special, Tensho, style) who lived in Japan in the latter half of the Edo period.

Gengen TANABE (a male, 1796 - January 21, 1859) was a calligrapher and Tenkoku artist (a carver who carved Chinese characters in the special, Tensho, style) who lived in Japan in the latter half of the Edo period.

sen.j: 名は祐憲または憲、
sen.e: His name was Hironori or or nori.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: His name was Hironori or or nori.
His name was Hironori or Nori.
sen.cmt: 余分なor削除しました。Nori大文字にしました。

sen.j: 字は伯表、号 (称号)は玄々の他に尚松竹楓園・東田居などがある。
sen.e: He was also called Hakuhyo, and used Shochikurinfuen or Todenkyo in addition to Gengen as the title for his profession.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処伯表, 尚松竹楓園・東田居： 読み方不明
sen.e: He was also called Hakuhyo, and used Shochikurinfuen or Todenkyo in addition to Gengen as the title for his profession.
He was also called Hakuhyo, and used Joshochikukeien (尚松竹楓園) or Higashitai (東田居) in addition to Gengen as the title for his profession.
sen.cmt: 尚松竹楓園→Joshochikukeien［読み不明］東田居→Higashitai[読み不明］

sen.j: 通称は飛騨。
sen.e: He was commonly called Hida.
He was commonly called Hida.
He was commonly called Hida.

sen.j: 京都の人。
sen.e: He came from Kyoto.
He came from Kyoto.
He came from Kyoto.

sen.j: 略伝
sen.e: Summary of his personal history
Summary of his personal history
Summary of his personal history

sen.j: 東寺外山吹町の富裕な家に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born into a rich family in Yamabuki-cho, outside To-ji Temple.
He was born into a rich family in Yamabuki-cho, outside To-ji Temple.
He was born into a rich family in Yamabuki-cho, outside To-ji Temple.

sen.j: 幼い頃より書画を好んだ。
sen.e: He liked calligraphy and paintings from his childhood.
He liked calligraphy and paintings from his childhood.
He liked calligraphy and paintings from his childhood.

sen.j: 武元登々庵に就いて書を学び、高野山空居より空海の書法を授かる。
sen.e: He learned calligraphy from Totoan TAKEMOTO, and was also bestowed Kukai's calligraphic method on by Koyasankukyo.
He learned calligraphy from Totoan TAKEMOTO, and was also bestowed Kukai's calligraphic method on by Koyasankukyo.
He learned calligraphy from Totoan TAKEMOTO, and was also bestowed Kukai's calligraphic method on by Koyasan Kukyo.

sen.j: 画は中林竹洞に師事した。
sen.e: He studied painting under Chikuto NAKABAYASHI.
He studied painting under Chikuto NAKABAYASHI.
He studied painting under Chikuto NAKABAYASHI.

sen.j: 篆刻に巧みで、中年以後は磁印の創作に没頭。
sen.e: He was good at carving Tensho-style Chinese characters and devoted his life in his middle ages and later at creating Jiin (the china on which a seal pattern was carved).
He was good at carving Tensho-style Chinese characters and devoted his life in his middle ages and later at creating Jiin (the china on which a seal pattern was carved).
He was good at carving Tensho-style Chinese characters and devoted his life in his middle ages and later at creating Jiin (the china on which a seal pattern was carved).

sen.j: 粘土で鈕式を作って、印文を刻し焼成して磁印を製作する法を開発している。
sen.e: He developed a Jiin-generating method in which clay was used to make chusiki (the portion of a jiin to be grasped by a hand) and Chinese characters for a seal) were carved on it and was baked.
He developed a Jiin-generating method in which clay was used to make chusiki (the portion of a jiin to be grasped by a hand) and Chinese characters for a seal) were carved on it and was baked.
He developed a Jiin-generating method in which clay was used to make chusiki (the portion of a jiin to be grasped by a hand) and Chinese characters for a seal) were carved on it and was baked.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを削除しました。

sen.j: その精妙さは大いに賞賛された。
sen.e: The level of its exquisiteness was admired.
The level of its exquisiteness was admired.
The level of its exquisiteness was admired.

sen.j: 東寺に候人として仕え、のちに法眼位に叙されている。
sen.e: He served To-ji Temple as a konin (who lived and worked there) and awarded Hogen i (the second highest of priests' rank).
He served To-ji Temple as a konin (who lived and worked there) and awarded Hogen i (the second highest of priests' rank).
He served To-ji Temple as a konin (who lived and worked there) and awarded Hogen (the second highest rank in the hierarchy of Buddhist priests).
sen.cmt: 法眼→ Hogen (the second highest rank in the hierarchy of Buddhist priests)

sen.j: 頼山陽、青木木米、僧雲華などの当代一流の文人と交流している。
sen.e: He was intimate with first-grade literary persons at that time, such as Sanyo RAI, Mokubei AOKI and Unge, a priest.
He was intimate with first-grade literary persons at that time, such as Sanyo RAI, Mokubei AOKI and Unge, a priest.
He was intimate with first-grade literary persons at that time, such as Sanyo RAI, Mokubei AOKI and Unge, a priest.

sen.j: 享年66。
sen.e: He died at the age of 66.
He died at the age of 66.
He died at the age of 66.

sen.j: 南部狐塚（京都市南区唐橋）に埋葬される。
sen.e: He was buried at Nanbu-Kozuka (located in Karahashi, Minami Ward, Kyoto City).
He was buried at Nanbu-Kozuka (located in Karahashi, Minami Ward, Kyoto City).
He was buried at Nanbu-Kozuka (located in Karahashi, Minami Ward, Kyoto City).

sen.e: The books he wrote
Books he wrote

sen.e: Inpu (a compilation of seal marks)
Inpu (a compilation of seal marks)
Inpu (a compilation of seal marks)

sen.j: 『玄々瓷印譜』一帙二冊 天保2年（1831年）
sen.e: "Gengen Shi Inpu," two books in a chitsu (a container to keep books made of Japanese papers in it), in 1831.
"Gengen Shi Inpu," two books in a chitsu (a container to keep books made of Japanese papers in it), in 1831.
"Gengen Shi Inpu," two books in a chitsu (a container to keep books made of Japanese papers in it), in 1831.

sen.j: 『拾玉印譜』
sen.e: "Shugyoku Inpu"
"Shugyoku Inpu"
